awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2022: Defining the biochemical mechanisms of microtubule shrinking and nucleation by combining innovative experiments and simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Most cells grow, remodel and divide using the cytoskeleton – a network of protein that function as a kind of scaffolding that gives shape and structure to the cell interior. A critical aspect of the cytoskeleton are small protein subunits called microtubules. Despite decades of study, many aspects of microtubule function and behavior are poorly understood. The Fellow will combine wet lab experiments with computational simulations to determine how new microtubules form, and how existing microtubules shrink (two behaviors critical for microtubule function). This award also supports the development of a local scientific outreach program.

Microtubule shrinking and spontaneous assembly (‘nucleation’) rates ultimately derive from the structural and biochemical properties of αβ-tubulin subunits. It remains challenging to determine how interactions between subunits less than 10 nm long determine microtubule assembly dynamics on the μm scale. This uncertainty limits mechanistic understanding of how microtubule behavior can change between cells in the same organism, between different species, and even across taxa. To investigate how microtubules shrink, the Fellow will use pioneering measurements of mixed mutant-wild type microtubules complemented by kinetic Monte Carlo simulations. This hybrid computational-experimental approach will test hypotheses about mechanisms of microtubule dynamics in ways that were not previously possible. To understand how new microtubules form spontaneously, or ‘nucleate’, the Fellow will create new codes to simulate microtubule nucleation from unpolymerized αβ-tubulin.  With these simulations, the Fellow will define the sequence of tubulin oligomers that leads to a new microtubule, and how the sequence depends on biochemical properties of αβ-tubulin. Training objectives include learning new skills in advanced microscopy, computational simulations and protein work. To broaden participation in science, the fellow will lead a microscope-based outreach program with a local middle school that serves a diverse student population. Lesson plans and materials will be made publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Goals

The NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship # 2209298 awarded to Dr. Lauren McCormick funded a multidisciplinary study of microtubules, essential polymers of tubulin protein that are required for eukaryotic life. McCormick used simulations and experiments to investigate fundamental biochemical mechanisms that govern microtubule dynamics, and how these mechanisms are tuned by evolution.  Aim 1) use a slow-shrinking, allosteric tubulin mutant to study how microtubules disassemble, and Aim 2) design and deploy kinetic monte carlo simulations to study how microtubules spontaneously self-assemble without a structural template. During the award period, McCormick launched two more projects that fall under Area 2 (rules of life) criteria: defining the role of beta tubulin nucleotide state in regulating microtubule growth, and direclty characterizing microtubules from a parasitic organism for the first time, to learn how evolution tunes microtubule dynamics between species.

Key Discoveries and Scientific Importance

Aim 1: Disassembly) McCormick made pioneering measurements of mixed mutant-wild type microtubules, using human recombinant tubulin and a slow-shrinking, allosteric tubulin mutant. Her assays revealed unexpected but exciting effects on microtubule transition frequencies (from growth to shrinking, or vice versa), as well as unique end-specific dynamics between mutant and wild-type. She is using her results to constrain follow-up simulations (which she designed for this aim) to test mechanistic hypotheses about her data, to further investigate the poorly-understood mechanisms that control dynamic microtubule transitions.

Aim 2: Spontaneous self-assembly) McCormick designed and implemented kinetic Monte Carlo simulations of spontaneous self-assembly. Using these new codes, McCormick's work suggests that spontaneous self-assembly occurs via layer-based accretion of rectangular tubulin oligomers, which grow by accumulating new tubulin layers at the edges. Simulations also indicate that the inherent GTPase activity of tubulin antagonizes accretion.

Third project: Role of nucleotide in growth) McCormick provided strong new evidence to settle a decades-old debate about how the nucleotide state of beta tubulin regulates microtubule growth. In her publication, she capitalized on a microtubule's inherent polarity to show that nucleotide regulates growth through an interface-acting ('trans') mechanism. Her work also demonstrated that the lesser-studied microtubule "minus" end is a useful tool for future mechanistic studies. 

Final project: Microtubule variation between species and evolution) McCormick performed the first direct characterization of microtubules from parasitic Leishmania tarentolae outside a cellular environment, where microtubule regulatory proteins can alter/influence inherent microtubule dynamics. Using purified protein and IRM, she showed that L. tarentolae microtubules exhibit strikingly different dynamics from human microtubules. To her knowledge, she is the first to characterize these L. tarentolae microtubules outside a cellular environment, and therefore to conclusively show species-specific differences between the dynamics of human and L. tarentolae microtubules.

In addition to a peer reviewed first author publication, this fellowship led to multiple invited talks at professional conferences and multiple travel awards. McCormick used these opportunities to share her findings with the broader scientific community. Finally, McCormick also achieved all of her training goals, which included learning new techniques for her portfolio: protein work, several programming languages, kinetic Monte Carlo simulations, and interference reflection microscopy (IRM); she then established IRM in her mentor's lab.

Broader Impacts and Public Engagement

This award supported McCormick in pursuing multiple avenues of science outreach that reached underrepresented populations in STEM. McCormick spearheaded a new outreach program connecting scientist volunteers with a local school in Dallas that serves underrepresented populations. McCormick recruited scientist volunteers and led microscope-based activities with 4th and 5th grade science classes, and also provided ad-hoc training in microscope usage to teachers of each class. McCormick also volunteered frequently with other local outreach efforts that were aimed at broadening participation in science. Overall, McCormick's outreach efforts reached ~600 students total during the award period. 

In addition to traditional outreach, McCormick prioritized opportunities to mentor multiple junior researchers one-on-one at her institution, including members of underrepresented groups in STEM. She also served the postdoctoral population at her insitution as Vice President of the Postdoctoral Association, where she advocated for fellow postdocs, most notably on the issues of fair pay and benefits, and support for parents. She also gave lectures and talks for both outreach and training, including a talk that taught fellow postdocs how to identify mentors for personal and professional growth.

Summary

McCormick's work under this fellowship addressed multiple areas of intense interest at the heart of microtubule dynamics, and builds towards general principles for how microtubules function in eukaryotic life. McCormick's work has advanced understanding of how microtubules assemble, disassemble, and differ between species, enabling follow-up studies of how microtubule mechanisms are tuned by microtubule protein (tubulin) variation, protein mutation, and evolutionary adaptation.
